title.narrative: Collaborative Seed Programme under the Nigeria-Netherlands Seed Partnership

description.narrative: By 2024, CSP will have reached the following target groups: smallholder men and women farmers, seed companies and members of seed entrepeneurs association, policy makers, researchers from agricultural research institutes, staff of Nigerian seed regulatory bodies, development partners investing in seed sector development in Nigeria.

The Collaborative Seed Programme (CSP) brings together Nigerian and Dutch seed sector stakeholders with the aim to enhance the performance of the Nigerian seed sector. It takes a systemic approach for sustainably addressing key challenges in the seed sector. CSP contributes to the vision of the National Seed Road Map (NSRM) of Nigeria being the seed sector to become more competitive, resilient, profitable, innovative and adaptive, sustainable, inclusive, resistant and transparent. In order to achieve and contribute to this vision, the NSRM outlines 22 Strategic Innovation Pathways (SIPs) with ambitions and steps. The CSP contributes to the implementation of eight selected SIPs. These selected SIPs shape what are referred to as CSP Topics. The following topics have been selected: (i) decentralization of seed quality assurance; (ii) extension on seed and cultivation practices; (iii) seed company marketing and promotion; (iv) institutional markets; (v) sector governance and coordination; (iv) alignment of donor interventions; (vii) plant variety protection; and (viii) variety release.

The project aims to contribute to improved sustainable food, income and nutrition security of rural households in Nigeria, by improving farmers’ access to and use of quality seed of improved varieties. The outcomes for the eight CSP topics are as follows: (1) Decentralized SQA systems for key food and nutrition security crops established and operational; (2) Challenges related to the use of quality seed, improved varieties and advanced cultivation practices addressed; (3) Capacity of Nigerian and Dutch seed companies to promote varieties increased; (4) Seed market distortion by institutional buyers reduced; (5) Coordination, alignment and accountability among seed sector stakeholders enhanced; (6) Alignment and sharing of information contributing to NSRM implementation among development partners enhanced; (7) System for plant variety protection in place and operational (8) Efficiency and effectiveness of variety release system improved.

title.narrative: Progress Report Collaborative Seed Programme Nigeria, Inception phase: 1 November 2020 – 31 May 2021

description.narrative: The Collaborative Seed Programme (CSP) under the Nigeria-Netherlands Seed Partnership (NNSP) aims to improve farmers’ access to and use of quality seed of improved varieties to sustainably increase agricultural productivity. The report concerns the programme’s inception phase which ran from 1 November 2020 to 31 May 2021.
